details.reused_text: ALICANTE, Spain (AP) ï¿½ Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Unionï¿½s energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

Postmedia Network Inc. | 365 Bloor Street East, Toronto, Ontario, M4W 3L4 | 416-383-2300
Article content
Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUÂ´s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

Article content
The project will first connect two plants in northern Portugal and northern Spain and then involve a pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea from the northeastern Spanish port of Barcelona to Franceï¿½s Marseille.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
She said the EU planned to produce 10 million metric tons of renewable hydrogen by 2030 and to import another 10 million tons.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Unionï¿½s energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

ï¿½We are strengthening European Unionï¿½s strategic autonomy and energy security at a moment when solidarity among Europeans is essential to reduce energy dependency on countries that use energy as a blackmailing tool,ï¿½ Sanchez said, in reference to Russia and the gas crisis that has emerged since the war in Ukraine.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.

ALICANTE, Spain (AP) ï¿½ Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Unionï¿½s energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

The project will first connect two plants in northern Portugal and northern Spain and then involve a pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea from the northeastern Spanish port of Barcelona to Franceï¿½s Marseille.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUÂ´s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
The project is expected to cost 2.5 billion euros ($2.6 billion).

Article content
Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUÂ´s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.

ALICANTE, Spain (AP) ï¿½ Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Unionï¿½s energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.
ï¿½Today, the Iberian Peninsula is becoming a major European energy gateway to the world,ï¿½ Von der Leyen said at a joint press briefing.

Article content
The project will first connect two plants in northern Portugal and northern Spain and then involve a pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea from the northeastern Spanish port of Barcelona to Franceï¿½s Marseille.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.

Article content
The announcement came after a meeting between Sanchez, his French and Portuguese counterparts and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen in the eastern Spanish city of Alicante.
ALICANTE, Spain -- Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Union's energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

The project will first connect two plants in northern Portugal and northern Spain and then involve a pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea from the northeastern Spanish port of Barcelona to Franceï¿½s Marseille.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
She said the EU planned to produce 10 million metric tons of renewable hydrogen by 2030 and to import another 10 million tons.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Union's energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

ï¿½We are strengthening European Unionï¿½s strategic autonomy and energy security at a moment when solidarity among Europeans is essential to reduce energy dependency on countries that use energy as a blackmailing tool,ï¿½ Sï¿½nchez said, in reference to Russia and the gas crisis that has emerged since the war in Ukraine.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
ALICANTE, Spain -- Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Union's energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.
ï¿½Today, the Iberian Peninsula is becoming a major European energy gateway to the world,ï¿½ Von der Leyen said at a joint press briefing.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

The project will first connect two plants in northern Portugal and northern Spain and then involve a pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea from the northeastern Spanish port of Barcelona to Franceï¿½s Marseille.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
ALICANTE, Spain -- Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
The project is expected to cost 2.5 billion euros ($2.6 billion).
The announcement came after a meeting between Sï¿½nchez, his French and Portuguese counterparts and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen in the eastern Spanish city of Alicante.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.
She said the EU planned to produce 10 million metric tons of renewable hydrogen by 2030 and to import another 10 million tons.
The announcement came after a meeting between Sï¿½nchez, his French and Portuguese counterparts and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen in the eastern Spanish city of Alicante.

The pipeline is aimed at making the European Union's energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.
ï¿½Today, the Iberian Peninsula is becoming a major European energy gateway to the world,ï¿½ Von der Leyen said at a joint press briefing.

The project will first connect two plants in northern Portugal and northern Spain and then involve a pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea from the northeastern Spanish port of Barcelona to Franceï¿½s Marseille.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.

By IAIN SULLIVAN
Associated Press

ALICANTE, Spain (AP) ï¿½ Spain, France and Portugal have agreed to build a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and Europe by 2030.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Union more energy independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine that precipitated an energy crisis.
Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez says the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to carry some 2 million tons of hydrogen to France annually, or 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Union more energy independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine that precipitated an energy crisis.

By IAIN SULLIVAN
Associated Press

ALICANTE, Spain (AP) ï¿½ Spain, France and Portugal have agreed to build a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and Europe by 2030.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Union more energy independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine that precipitated an energy crisis.
Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez says the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to carry some 2 million tons of hydrogen to France annually, or 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.

By IAIN SULLIVAN
Associated Press

ALICANTE, Spain (AP) ï¿½ Spain, France and Portugal have agreed to build a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and Europe by 2030.
Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez says the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to carry some 2 million tons of hydrogen to France annually, or 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.
The project is expected to cost 2.5 billion euros ($2.6 billion).
The announcement was made after a meeting Friday between Sï¿½nchez, his French and Portuguese counterparts and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez says the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to carry some 2 million tons of hydrogen to France annually, or 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.

By IAIN SULLIVAN

ALICANTE, Spain (AP) ï¿½ Spain, France and Portugal have agreed to build a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and Europe by 2030.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Union more energy independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine that precipitated an energy crisis.
Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez says the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to carry some 2 million tons of hydrogen to France annually, or 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.
Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez says the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to carry some 2 million tons of hydrogen to France annually, or 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.

ALICANTE, Spain (AP) ï¿½ Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Unionï¿½s energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

The project will first connect two plants in northern Portugal and northern Spain and then involve a pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea from the northeastern Spanish port of Barcelona to Franceï¿½s Marseille.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
She said the EU planned to produce 10 million metric tons of renewable hydrogen by 2030 and to import another 10 million tons.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Unionï¿½s energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

ï¿½We are strengthening European Unionï¿½s strategic autonomy and energy security at a moment when solidarity among Europeans is essential to reduce energy dependency on countries that use energy as a blackmailing tool,ï¿½ Sï¿½nchez said, in reference to Russia and the gas crisis that has emerged since the war in Ukraine.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.

ALICANTE, Spain (AP) ï¿½ Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Unionï¿½s energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.
ï¿½Today, the Iberian Peninsula is becoming a major European energy gateway to the world,ï¿½ Von der Leyen said at a joint press briefing.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

The project will first connect two plants in northern Portugal and northern Spain and then involve a pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea from the northeastern Spanish port of Barcelona to Franceï¿½s Marseille.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.

ALICANTE, Spain (AP) ï¿½ Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
The project is expected to cost 2.5 billion euros ($2.6 billion).
The announcement came after a meeting between Sï¿½nchez, his French and Portuguese counterparts and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen in the eastern Spanish city of Alicante.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.
